docs.title: The CS 1x book: Fall 2025
docs.text:
This book is the official document repository for the Caltech CS 1x course (Intermediate Computer Programming).

The course instructor is Mike Vanier. See the syllabus for administrative information.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
The CS 1x collaboration policies determine if, and how much, you are allowed to collaborate with other students while working on your assignments.

Please read this document to the very end, because you are responsible for abiding by all the rules set forth here. Failure to abide by these rules may cause you to get sent to the Board of Control, and that is not pleasant for anyone concerned. Therefore, we want to be extra clear on what constitutes fair collaboration in this course.

Note

In many places in this document, you will read that some kind of behavior is strictly forbidden. We are not trying to scare you or intimidate you, and we're not trying to be jerks. We just want to make absolutely sure that you know what the rules are, and saying that something is strictly forbidden is pretty unambiguous. (We apologize in advance if you find this annoying.)

docs.title: Basic policy
docs.text:
You are welcome to collaborate informally on your assignments with other individuals who are taking or have taken the class, but you must write all of your own code and you must not look at other students' code, except to help them as described below. Copying another student's code verbatim or nearly verbatim (from a file, a whiteboard, a screen share or anywhere else) is not acceptable and is an Honor Code violation. Taking another student's file and modifying it to make it look different is definitely not acceptable and is an Honor Code violation. Consulting a printed or electronically displayed version of another student's code and referring to it while you write your own code is not acceptable either, and is also an Honor Code violation. Having someone dictate code while you type isn't acceptable either. Basically, you have to do your own work.

Getting advice on algorithms or syntactic details of the language, or suggestions on how to debug a part of your program that isn't working, is fine.

All of the above also applies if you are getting tutored for the course, officially or unofficially.

All of the above also applies to student work from previous years. We re-use some problems in assignments, and copying answers from an assignment that was submitted in previous years is an Honor Code violation just as much as copying from a student who is currently taking the course.

docs.title: Helping others and the "50-foot rule"
docs.text:
It is common for students to want to help other students to write and debug their assignments. While we prefer that you go to one of the course teaching assistants when you need help on the assignments (it doesn't matter which one), we don't forbid you from seeking help from other students or offering your help to other students. However, we do insist on some guidelines to make the process fair for everyone.

When you are helping another student with their homework, you are acting as an unofficial teaching assistant, and thus you must behave like one. A teaching assistant will not just tell you the answer or dictate code to you; he/she will help you work through the problem so that you understand what you are doing wrong. If you don't have the time or the inclination to do this, do not assist other students. If you just give them your code, you are violating the Honor Code and both you and the people you are giving the code to may be in for some serious consequences.

As a way of clarifying the way in which you can help other students (especially when it comes to debugging their code), we want you to obey the "50 foot rule". This rule states that if you help another student with their programming problems (including debugging), you must not consult your own code while doing so. Specifically, we ask that your own code be at least 50 feet away i.e. not visible to you or the person you are helping while you are helping them. (It doesn't have to be exactly 50 feet; the point is that you can't see your code while helping the other person, and you shouldn't run back and forth between your computer with your code and the computer of the person you're helping.) The slogan of the 50-foot rule is: "Help them with your brain, not with your code." Please do not try to find a loophole kind of way around this e.g. projecting your code on a building 50 feet away; that is clearly not what we mean. Posting your code on a pastebin-like internet site, emailing your code to other people, sharing your screen with your code on it, printing it out, or even referring to it on your laptop while helping someone else, are all clear violations of the collaboration policy for this course. Also, we don't want you to put your code up on a computer in a room 50 feet away from where you're helping someone and run back and forth, dictating a line at a time. If you can't help them without consulting your code, don't help them. Refer them to a teaching assistant.

Note

The 50-foot rule only applies when helping another student in person.

Helping another student using teleconferencing software like Zoom, Skype, Discord etc. is covered below, but one aspect of it is that screen sharing is not permitted.

We realize that it's more convenient to ask someone in your house for help than to walk all the way to the Annenberg building. A possible solution is to get to know a TA and meet with them in their dorm room (if they are willing).

docs.title: Use and abuse of pseudocode
docs.text: In the past, some students have been called in to the BoC because of very similar code that was ultimately traced to pseudocode written on a whiteboard which was almost exactly like the final code. Pseudocode is supposed to be an informal, non-executable description of an algorithm. If you write or consult pseudocode which is (say) 80% or more of the way to being actual runnable code as a way to do an end run around the collaboration policies, be advised that we and the BoC are well aware of this problem and you will not get away with it. On the other hand, if you (or a TA) write out or read pseudocode which is a human-readable description of an algorithm without any actual code in it, you are fine.

docs.title: Teleconferencing software (e.g. Zoom, Discord)
docs.text:
If you use teleconferencing software (like Zoom) or software with teleconferencing capabilities (like Discord), you may not share your screen with another student (unless they are a course teaching assistant), whether to help them or to get help from them. This also applies to non-students (again, with the exception of the course instructor).

Also, it is strictly forbidden to dictate code over teleconferencing software. This is consistent with the rules in the other sections of this document.

docs.title: Discussion boards and chat programs (e.g. Piazza, Slack, Discord)
docs.text:
You are strictly forbidden from posting code which answers or even partially answers a problem to a discussion board (such as Piazza) unless it's a private message to one or more instructors/TAs. If this happens you may lose the ability to use the discussion board for any purpose.

Note

This has been a problem for some students in the past. There is nothing wrong with posting code to Piazza as long as it is a private message to the instructors. Posting a public message containing code is another matter, and we reserve the right to ban you from using Piazza if this happens.

This also applies to programs with chat features that are not used in the course (like Slack), or even email for that matter.

docs.title: Use of websites
docs.text:
It is strictly forbidden to post any of the problems from the assignments onto websites (for instance, Stack Overflow), and anyone caught doing this will be charged with an Honor Code violation. This includes problems that are similar to assignment problems even if not identical. If you find a discussion of course-related material on internet websites, you may read it as long as the discussion is not about a problem that is identical to or very similar to a problem on one of the course assignments. However, do not transcribe code from the internet into your homework submissions.

It is strictly forbidden to look at any solutions to any previous years' CS 1x work posted on internet code repository sites (including but not limited to GitHub, GitLab, BitBucket, etc.). It is also strictly forbidden to put your own code in such a repository unless (a) it is a private repository, and (b) you do not allow anyone else access to this private repository. You may also not fork any such repositories that you might happen to find; we will consider this prima facie evidence of intent to plagiarize.

docs.title: Use of code hinting / AI software
docs.text:
Examples of code hinting / AI software include:

  • Github Copilot
  • ChatGPT
  • Claude

as well as many others.

You are strictly forbidden to use code hinting software in any way for any part of this course. If your editor is configured to use code hinting software (for instance, if you have a ChatGPT extension installed in Visual Studio Code) you must disable it or uninstall it when working on your CS 1x assignments. The whole point of taking a programming course is to learn to program better, not to learn how to ask an AI to do it for you. (Of course, when you are writing code for a job, or for fun, use whatever tools you like.)

Prompts

Any use of AI prompts in your code will be dealt with very harshly!

docs.text:
These are things which you are required to do while working on your CS 1x assignments.

Item Assignments Turn in only your own programs/code Yes Indicate the names of any collaborators on a program Yes

docs.title: Consequences for violating these policies
docs.text:
Be aware that letting another student copy from you is just as bad as copying from another student, and can get you into just as much trouble.

Be aware that we use plagiarism detection software to check for copying, and students with assignments that are suspiciously similar will be referred to the Board of Control (BoC).

docs.title: Finally...
docs.text:
If you have any questions about the course collaboration policies, please send an email to the course instructor, Mike Vanier. Do not ask the teaching assistants; they may not give you the best answer.

We realize that the vast majority of you (hopefully all of you) have no intention of cheating or overcollaboration in any way, and we hope that this collaboration policy won't get in the way of your enjoyment of the course.

docs.title: Course syllabus
docs.text: This is the course syllabus for CS 1x: (Intermediate Computer Programming), Fall 2025.

docs.title: Course instructor
docs.text:
• Michael Vanier (he/him)

Mike's email address is mvanier@cms.caltech.edu.

docs.title: Teaching assistants
docs.text: Teaching assistants are TBA.

docs.title: Office hours
docs.text: Office hour times and locations will be posted on the course Piazza page.

docs.title: External websites
docs.text:
For homework submission and grading, we will use GradeScope (link to be added).

For course-related discussions, we will use Piazza.

Piazza notes:

  • Please use Piazza instead of emailing the instructor or the TAs.

  • Please make a post private to the instructor and TAs if it could give away all or part of an answer to a problem on an assignment (especially when posting code).

docs.title: Recommended textbooks
docs.text: There is no required text. There may be recommended readings (generally web pages) listed as part of the lectures and assignments, but none of them are required.

docs.title: Course overview
docs.text:
From the Caltech catalog:

CS 1x. Intermediate Computer Programming. 6 units (2-2-2): first term. Prerequisites: Enrollment by instructor permission only. Students must be placed into this course via the CS placement test. An intermediate course on computer programming emphasizing the program design process and pragmatic programming skills. It will use the Java programming language and will assume previous programming experience such as an AP CS A course. Material will focus on more advanced topics such as recursion, exception handling and object-oriented programming. Program development and maintenance skills including debugging, testing, and documentation will also be taught. Assignments will include problems drawn from fields such as graphics, numerics, networking, and games. At the end of the course, students will be ready to learn other programming languages in courses such as CS 11, and will also be ready to take more in-depth courses such as CS 2 and CS 4.

This course is for students with programming experience. It will be primarily concerned with program design, which is a nebulous term which describes how to write "good" code (as opposed to code that just works). There are many different aspects to program design; in this course we will cover the most basic of them, and CS 3 will go deeper into software engineering topics.

docs.title: Topics covered
docs.text:
• Incremental programming as a development strategy
  • Recursion, and specifically how to correctly write a recursive algorithm
  • Exception handling, and how to use it correctly
  • Separation of concerns, leading to more manageable/scalable code
  • Making code easy to test
  • Refactoring
  • The D.R.Y. principle (Don't Repeat Yourself)
  • Design patterns, especially object-oriented design
  • Antipatterns and how to avoid them

docs.title: Learning objectives
docs.text:
By the end of this course, you should be able to

  • write and debug Java programs of up to 1000 lines;
  • decompose problems into classes in a reasonable way:
  • have a deeper understanding of what constitutes a well-designed program;
  • write recursive algorithms without fear!

At that point, you will be well-prepared to take CS 2, which will cover fundamental algorithms and data structures.

docs.title: Lectures
docs.text:
Lectures will be held once a week, on Wednesdays at 3 PM in Annenberg room 104.

In lectures, we will be interactively reviewing code and revising and improving it. Lectures will thus be highly interactive and not passive "brain-dump" experiences.

Attendance and participation currently do not count towards the final grade. However, we strive to make lectures interactive and do a lot of live coding during lectures. Missing out on this will deprive you of many of the benefits of the course. All lecture materials will be posted.

docs.title: Due dates
docs.text: Assignment due dates are TBA.

docs.title: Submission
docs.text: Completed assignments will be submitted to CodePost (https://codepost.io). If you are registered for the course, we will add you to the course CodePost page.

docs.title: Grading scheme
docs.text:
CS 1x is graded pass/fail.

There will be 7 assignments. There will be no exams.

Each assignment will be given an integer grade from 0 to 3 points. These mean the following:

Grade Meaning 3 All good; no serious problems 2 Mostly correct, but some small problems 1 Partially correct, but with some serious problems 0 Not correct at all

In addition, students are expected to do 3 code reviews during the term (see below for more on code reviews). Each code review is worth 1 point. You may do more, but they will not be worth extra points.

Attendance is taken during lectures. Attendance is worth points based on the percentage of lectures you attended according to this scale:

% lectures attended Points 50-100% 2 25-50% 1 < 25% 0

The maximum number of points is thus 21 + 3 + 2 = 26 points. The pass threshold will be 18 points (around 70%).

docs.title: Code reviews
docs.text:
In addition to just submitting your assignments and having them graded, we will also be conducting code reviews with each student. These will happen after you have submitted your assignment. A code review might take only a minute (if everything is perfect), or up to 20 minutes (if there is a lot to discuss).

In a code review (which will be just you and the instructor) we will not concentrate on debugging (that's for office hours) but on making sure that the overall design of your code is reasonable. You are welcome to disagree with us; maybe you can convince us that your design is better than the one we had in mind!

Note

There will be no code reviews for assignment 1.

docs.title: Reworks
docs.text: All assignments can be reworked for up to one week from the time when you received your grade for the assignment. If a rework has not been submitted after one week, the original grade will stand.

docs.title: Late days
docs.text:
Each student gets 5 "late days" for the entire term. Each late day allows you to submit an assignment one day late. You are allowed to use more than one late day on an assignment if you need to (but no more than 2 late days per assignment).

In order to use late days, you must specify on the assignment when you submit it:

  • how many late days you have used for the assignment,
  • how many late days you have used up for the entire term.

Please write this information in a comment at the top of one of the code files which you will submit as part of your assignment.

Once you have used up all of your late days, you can't use any more.

If you don't specify any late days in your assignment submission, we will assume that you are not using any for the assignment.

You are never required to use late days, even if you submit an assignment late, but if you do submit an assignment late and don't use late days, you will receive late penalties.

Restrictions on late days

There are these restrictions on the use of late days:

  1. To keep you from using up all of your late days on a single assignment, you cannot use more than 2 late days on any single assignment.

  2. You cannot use late days on reworks. As specified above, a rework which is late is not graded.

docs.title: Extensions
docs.text:
Normally, if you need an extension, just use your late days.

Students may request additional extensions for assignments due to unusual circumstances (e.g. health problems). These extensions have to be approved by the course instructor (Mike). If you get an extension, you must indicate that at the top of your README.md file you submit e.g. something like this:

(One day extension granted by Mike Vanier until 10/31.)

This is so your grader knows not to take off late points.

docs.title: Late penalties
docs.text: If an assignment is late when first submitted, and late days are not being used, points are deducted at the rate of 0.5 points/day. These points can't be regained through rework.

docs.title: Software
docs.text:
In this course, we will be using the Java programming language exclusively. Instructions to install Java are included in the first assignment.

Other than that, you will only need a terminal program and a plain text editor. You can use any editor you like, but we recommend the Visual Studio Code editor, which also provides access to a terminal.

docs.title: Academic integrity
docs.text:
Caltech's Honor Code states that: "No member of the Caltech community shall take unfair advantage of any other member of the Caltech community."

Understanding and avoiding plagiarism: plagiarism is the appropriation of another person's ideas, processes, results, or words without giving appropriate credit, and it violates the Honor Code in a fundamental way. You can find more information at this page.

docs.title: Collaboration policies
docs.text: The course collaboration policies are listed on this page. Please read them! You are responsible for knowing them, and you are liable for any penalties that may occur if you violate any of the policies.

docs.title: Diversity and inclusion
docs.text: You all belong in this class and as such should expect to be treated by your classmates and the course staff with respect. It is our goal, as the course staff, to provide an interesting and challenging environment that is conducive to your learning. If any incident occurs that challenges this commitment to a supportive and inclusive environment, please let the instructors know so the issue can be addressed!

docs.title: Accessibility
docs.text: We consider accessibility to be an extremely important issue. If some aspect of the course is making it more difficult for you to learn the material, we want to hear about it! We want this course to be an enjoyable experience for you, not a burden.

docs.title: Student Wellness
docs.text: It is very important to us that you take care of your mental wellness throughout the course. Everyone on the course staff is available to chat, and you can always attend office hours for a non-academic conversation if necessary.

docs.title: Students with documented disabilities
docs.text: Students who may need an academic accommodation based on the impact of a disability must initiate the request with Caltech Accessibility Services for Students (CASS). Professional staff will evaluate the request with required documentation, recommend reasonable accommodations, and prepare an Accommodation Letter for faculty dated in the current quarter in which the request is being made. Students should contact CASS as soon as possible, since timely notice is needed to coordinate accommodations. See http://cass.caltech.edu/ for more information.

In order to be able to submit this assignment (and any of the other assignments in this course), several things must have been done by now. PLEASE DO NOT SKIP THIS SECTION!

  • You should have read the course syllabus and the collaboration policies documents posted on this website. The last one is particularly important, because if you violate the collaboration policies, you may get sent to the Caltech Board of Control, which is never pleasant.

docs.title: Project: An interactive Tic-Tac-Toe game
docs.text: For this project, you will write a program that can play Tic-Tac-Toe against the user from the terminal.

docs.title: Learning objectives
docs.text:
• Learn the process of incremental software development.

  • Learn (or relearn) the basics of Java: classes, methods, and fields.

  • Learn about the private and public modifiers in Java and when to use them.

  • Start learning about how to use exceptions effectively. (We will go into this in much more detail in later assignments.)

  • Learn about terminal-based input and output in Java.

docs.title: Template code
docs.text:
To get you started, and to provide an implementation of the TicTacToeException class, we are providing a template file called lab1.zip. This can be found in the "Modules" section of the course Canvas page in the "Assignment code" module. You should download this, uncompress it, and use the tictactoe/TicTacToe1.java file as the starting point for your first program.

Note

Remove the // TODO comments, which are just placeholders for the code you are supposed to write.

docs.title: Incremental software development
docs.text:
The main theme of this assignment is incremental software development. This is not a body of knowledge as such; instead, it's an approach to the process of software development which we consider to be valuable.

Incremental software development is not complicated, and it's not Java-specific; you can do it in any language. The main aspects of it are as follows:

  1. Write up a document describing what you want your program to do. This doesn't have to be very detailed, but it will give you a place to start.

  2. Refine that document into "milestones", which are descriptions of a series of working programs which do some subset of the total functionality of the program. The last milestone will be the final version of the program. Each milestone will add more features, and some will modify features implemented in the last milestone.

  3. Write the program for milestone 1. Test it (formally or informally). When this is working, add the features of milestone 2, test them, and so on until all the programs are written.

In this assignment, we will be giving you the milestones, so you are only responsible for the last step.

For this assignment only, we are going to force you to write and submit separate programs for each milestone. So instead of one program (TicTacToe.java) you will write five programs: (TicTacToe1.java, TicTacToe2.java, etc. We want to see how you write code incrementally! Note, though, that this is no harder than writing just one program, since once you are finished with e.g. TicTacToe1.java, you will simply copy that file to TicTacToe2.java and continue editing. (The only thing you need to be careful of is that you change the name of the class from TicTacToe1 to TicTacToe2 etc.)

Note

For each program, only implement the features requested for that program. If you implement too much (e.g. in an extreme case, just writing the final program and copying it to the other programs) you won't get any credit for the over-implemented programs.

In the rest of the assignments, you will only be submitting the final version of the program. We still encourage you to develop in the incremental style for those assignments!

docs.title: Programming notes
docs.text:
We will be giving you high-level descriptions of the programs we want you to write. We will list all the methods we want you to implement. However, we will leave many aspects of the program up to your own judgment.

Usually, it will be obvious what the arguments of the methods should be. In some cases, we will spell this out, and in other cases, we won't. We expect you to make reasonable choices in the latter cases.

For now, all methods that we instruct you to write should be public unless we specifically say otherwise. However, you are free to write additional methods, and those should normally be private. Writing an additional method is a good choice when you see you need some functionality in multiple places. (We will talk more about this later; it is the D.R.Y. or "Don't Repeat Yourself" design principle).

And the most important note of all: Make sure you compile and run all of your programs, and that they do what they are supposed to do! It's easy to get lazy and just assume that your programs work, but in general, there will be small (or sometimes large) errors that need to be fixed. I like to use the motto "untested code is broken by definition" i.e. if it hasn't been tested, you can assume that it doesn't work.

docs.title: Programs to write
docs.text:
All programs will be in the Java "package" called tictactoe. This means that they should be in a directory called tictactoe and you will compile them from the directory below that e.g.

$ javac tictactoe/TicTacToe1.java

(The $ is just the terminal prompt; don't type that.) You will run them from the same directory:

$ java tictactoe.TicTacToe1

Now we will describe what the individual programs will do.

docs.title: TicTacToe1.java
docs.text:
For this program, first create the TicTacToe1 class, with a main method i.e. public static void main(String[] args).

Add a constructor and a board representation, initially empty. You can choose any reasonable board representation.

Add a display() method which, when called, will print the board to the terminal. (The display doesn't have to be fancy; you will improve it in later programs.)

In main(), create a board and print it by calling the display method.

docs.title: TicTacToe2.java
docs.text:
Copy your code for TicTacToe1.java to TicTacToe2.java.

In TicTacToe2.java, change the name of the class from TicTacToe1 to TicTacToe2.

Improve the display by printing the lines of the tic-tac-toe board. Print a blank line before and after the board. Make it look nice when printed!

Add a method called move() that puts an X or an O at a particular position in the tic-tac-toe grid. The arguments are the row coordinate (an int between 0 to 2, inclusive), the column coordinate (ditto) and the player to move (which you can represent however you see fit). This method throws a TicTacToeException (with a meaningful error message) if:

  • the move coordinates are invalid
  • the player is invalid (not X or O)
  • the position is occupied

The main() method should catch TicTacToeException exceptions and print the error message. You will need a try/catch block for this.

Test this program by putting some valid calls to move() in main() and printing the board. Make moves with both players.

docs.title: TicTacToe3.java
docs.text:
Warning

This program will probably be the biggest "jump" from the previous program in the assignment.

Copy your code for TicTacToe2.java to TicTacToe3.java.

Add a player field which represents the next player to move. Initialize it (in the constructor) to the "X" player.

Add a method isWin() which returns false if there is no win on the board for the current player, or true if there is a win for the current player. Try to make this reasonably elegant (not just a giant brute force enumeration of all possible wins, which we will not accept).

Add a method isFull() which returns true if the board is full, or false otherwise.

Add a method play() that allows you to play tic-tac-toe against yourself. (This will probably be the longest method that you will write in the program.) This method works as follows:

  • Check for draws (board full) before each move. If you find one, print a message indicating the draw and return.

  • Print a message indicating which player is to move (e.g. "X to move").

  • Print a prompt (e.g. "Enter move: ") and read in a line of input.

  • If q is input, quit the game.

  • Otherwise, extract the coordinates of the move (e.g. the line 0 2 would give 0 and 2).

  • Use the coordinates to call the play() function. Catch any TicTacToeException, print the error message, and continue. (You'll need to use a try/catch form for this.)

  • Display the board after each move.

  • Check for wins after each move. If you find one, print a message indicating the win and return.

Call play() from main(), so when the program runs, you can play the game against yourself.

docs.title: Programming notes for TicTacToe3.java
docs.text:
To read input in a Java program use the Scanner class (technically, java.util.Scanner, though you don't have to use the fully-qualified name).

To read a line of text, use the nextLine method of Scanner.

To split a string s on whitespace (space characters), do s.split("\\s+"). The \\s+ is a regular expression, which we may have more to say about later in the course.

Make sure you have meaningful and specific error messages for all bad inputs. Don't just say e.g. invalid input or you will lose marks.

There should be no inputs (other than e.g. control-C) that can crash the program. If any input causes the program to crash, you are not handling errors properly and you will lose marks.

Note

When we say "crash the program" we mean "cause the program to exit with an uncaught exception traceback".

docs.title: TicTacToe4.java
docs.text:
Add a computer player by writing a method called makeComputerMove(). It will generate a random legal move when called and make that move. (Note: it should be a random move, not just the first move available. All possible moves should be equally likely.) It can assume that it will only be called when the computer player is about to play (so the player field will contain the computer player's symbol).

Rewrite play() so it uses the computer player. The human player will randomly be assigned to either X or O. Print a line stating which player is X e.g. "Human player is X" or "Computer player is X" before the game starts. Also, change the win message to report "Computer player wins!" or "Human player wins!" as appropriate.

docs.title: Programming notes for TicTacToe4.java
docs.text:
ArrayLists are useful for storing the possible legal moves (ones where the player can move because the position is unoccupied). You can have two of them (one for rows and one for columns). You should use ArrayList<Integer> if you do this; ArrayList is an example of a Java "generic" type (a type which is parameterized over another type). Do not use ArrayList<Object>.

The Random class provides random number generators. The nextInt and nextBoolean methods of this class will be useful.

docs.title: TicTacToe5.java
docs.text:
Improve the computer player (i.e. the makeComputerMove method) in these ways:

  • If there is a win for the computer, the computer will always make that move.

  • If not, and if there is a win for the human opponent, it will always move to block that win.

Add Javadoc comments before all your methods. (You can do this in the other programs too, but it isn't required.) A good reference for writing Javadoc comments is here. You don't have to include every possible tag; the @param, @return, and @throws should be enough for now. In addition, each method's Javadoc comment should state what the method does (but not the implementation details).

Note

Methods that take no arguments don't need @param tags. Methods that return void don't need a @return tag. Methods that don't throw exceptions don't need @throws tags. Use your judgment.

Test your completed program by running it several times, checking to see that it does exactly what you expect. Allow the computer to win a few times to see if it selects the winning move. Try to trap it into a loss to see if it blocks a move that would allow you to win.

docs.title: To hand in
docs.text: Submit all your programs (TicTacToe1.java through TicTacToe5.java) to GradeScope as Assignment 1.

docs.title: Getting set up
docs.text: This part of the assignment describes how to get the course software up and running. Fortunately, this should be very easy.

docs.title: Installing Java
docs.text: The main Java download site is here. This is where you can find the most up-to-date Java versions. We recommend using the most recent version of Java instead of relying on whatever version of Java came with your computer, since the version on your computer may not have some features in the latest versions, and we may use those features. As of this writing, the latest version of Java is Java 25.

docs.title: Editing your code
docs.text:
You can use any code editor you want for this course, but we recommend Visual Studio Code, also known as "VS Code". VS Code is nice in that it works well with almost all programming languages, so you can use it throughout your programming career.

Some Java programmers like integrated development environments (IDEs) like IntelliJ. The main advantage of these is that support for various tools (like testing tools) is built-in. The main disadvantage is that these IDEs are heavyweight, have a long learning curve, and tend to organize code in "projects" with many files that are only there for the benefit of the IDE. Put simply, they make Java programming more complicated than it needs to be, at least from our perspective. (They are much more valuable to professional Java programmers working on very large code bases, but that isn't our use case.) We won't forbid you from using an IDE, but you will have to submit the exact code files we ask you to, and we will have to be able to compile and run them without using your IDE.

At the other extreme, you can get by with just a terminal editor like neovim. (Mike is very partial to working this way.)

docs.title: Getting familiar with the terminal
docs.text:
We will expect that you will be able to compile and run your programs from a terminal. Both Linux and MacOS are Unix systems, so they use Unix terminal commands. Compiling and running Java programs is straightforward on these systems. Windows has its own set of terminal commands. However, Windows also has a fantastic feature called Windows Subsystem for Linux, which isn't provided by default but which can easily be installed. This allows you to run a Linux system inside of Windows. You can use this to compile your Java programs, or you can work directly from Windows, as you like. One nice thing about the VS Code editor is that it includes an integrated terminal which allows you to run terminal commands without leaving your editor.

In addition to being able to compile and run Java programs, about the only other commands you'll need to know are those that create directories, move files between directories, and allow you to navigate between directories. You can easily find tutorials on these subjects on the internet.

docs.title: Learning Java
docs.text:
All of you know either Python or Java. We will be using Java exclusively in this course.

We expect that most of you know will know Java to some extent already, most likely from an AP course in high school. We will not be doing a Java tutorial in lectures, because we believe that even if you don't know Java, you can pick it up quickly if you know Python. Also, Java has excellent on-line documentation available, which we encourage you to consult.

Note

Assignment 1 is intended to be in part a Java refresher. If you are having any Java-specific problems, please ask the TAs or instructor for help! We don't expect you to be expert Java programmers at this point. (At the end of the course, you will be.)

Some web sites we recommend include:

  • The Java API This contains detailed documentation on the extensive Java code libraries. (One of the best thing about Java is that the code libraries are so large.)

  • The official Java tutorials. If you are unfamiliar with Java, or need a refresher, this is the place to start.

For very specific language-related questions, Google and Stack Overflow can be worthwhile resources, as can asking the TAs and instructor. (Of course, don't use Google or Stack Overflow to search for implementations of the assignment code!)

docs.title: Other software tools
docs.text:
All you need for this course is a terminal, a code editor and the basic Java installation.

Most Java programmers use build systems like Ant, Maven, or Gradle. We won't be using these, but if you know them you can use them.

Most programmers store their code in code repositories like Github. You can do this if you like, but you must make your repositories private and you must promise not to share your code with other students, even after the course is over. Teaching you to use Github is beyond the scope of the course1 but if you know it or are willing to learn it, it's worth using. In particular, it protects you from wiping out a lot of work accidentally because you entered the wrong command.

  1. We had to leave something for CS 3! ↩

docs.title: Compiling and running
docs.text:
Put all the code into a directory called sc (which is the name of the package). Then, from the directory above sc, do this to compile the files:

$ javac sc/*.java

To run the program, do this:

$ java sc.SC

This will appear to do nothing, but in fact the terminal will be waiting for you to enter some commands. These will be described below. In addition, the program can accept a number of (optional) command-line arguments, which are also described below.

docs.title: Supplied code
docs.text:
The template code file contains the following files:

  • Args.java
  • Input.java
  • Value.java
  • Registers.java
  • Ops.java
  • SC.java
  • ValueTest.java

You will be editing all of these except for Args.java and ValueTest.java.

docs.title: Description of the program
docs.text:
This program is longer than the programs you have seen so far, but you only need to add about 250 lines of code to complete it. Also, many of the lines are very obvious from the context, because they are slightly changed versions of other nearby code in the same file.

There are a couple of tricky spots in the program, and we'll be very clear about them in the descriptions below.

Here is a description of the various files, along with information about what you need to implement in each file. As usual, you need to replace comments of the form // TODO with your code.

docs.title: Overview of the program
docs.text:
This program is a terminal-based calculator. You enter commands into the terminal and it prints the results. It can also take inputs from files or directly from the command line.

The way the calculator works is a bit unusual, but if you've ever used an HP calculator, it will seem familiar. You enter the operands, which get pushed onto a stack. Then you enter the operator, which causes the computation to occur. The arguments are popped off the stack before the computation occurs and the result is pushed back onto the stack. Example: instead of typing 1 + 1 you type 1 1 +. Also, nothing gets printed unless you ask for it, so to see the result of 1 + 1 you have to type 1 1 + p (p means to print the top of the stack). You can also omit a lot of space characters, since commands are all one character long. Therefore, the previous line could have been written as 1 1 +p.

There's a lot more to this, but we'll get into the details below. Now we will discuss the files that make up the program.

docs.title: Args.java
docs.text:
This file defines the Args class that handles command-line argument processing. It's provided to you in completed form, since (let's face it) command-line argument processing isn't very interesting.

Here is the program's usage message:

Usage: java sc.SC [OPTION] [filename ...]
  -e expr  evaluate expression
  -h       display this help message and exit

Note that all command-line arguments are optional. Input to the calculator can come from three kinds of sources:

  • terminal input (System.in)
  • file input
  • a string

With no arguments, the program just reads input from the terminal.

The -h command prints the usage (help) message; the rest of the command-line arguments are ignored.

An optional argument of the form -e expr, where expr is a string containing calculator commands, causes these commands to be executed. There can be multiple -e expr arguments, and they are evaluated in order from left to right.

Any other arguments are expected to be file names. These files should contain calculator commands, and are read from and evaluated in order. If the special name - is included, then the terminal will be read from after everything else has been read from. (This is useful for reading commands from a file and then from the terminal.) If the - argument is not present but other -e arguments and/or filename arguments are present, the program will exit after running all the string and file input commands.

You can interleave -e expr commands and filenames, but the -e commands will always be executed first. If the - filename is included, all other filenames and -e expr commands will be evaluated first before reading commands from the terminal.

That's it for command-line argument processing. Most of the time, the program will be reading from a single -e expr command, a single filename, or only from the terminal input.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
Here are some examples of running the program with the -e command-line option. Note that you sometimes need to quote the arguments. If the expression has spaces, it has to be quoted. Also, the * character has a special meaning in the terminal1, so you have to quote that too. (As usual, the $ is the command-line prompt, which you don't type.)

$ java sc.SC -e 10p
10
$ java sc.SC -e "10 20+p"
30
$ java sc.SC -e "10 20*p"
200
$ java sc.SC -e 10 -e 20 -e "*" -e p
200

Don't be worried if you don't understand what's happening yet; all will be explained below.

docs.title: Value.java
docs.text:
This file defines the fundamental value type (an abstract type called Value) that the calculator commands work on. It's provided for you in completed form.

A Value can be either

  • an integer
  • a floating-point number (a Java double)
  • a string

A single Value object can conceptually be any one of these types. For this to work, we use the "algebraic datatype pattern" discussed in lecture 8 and define these subclasses of Value:

  • StringValue (for values that are strings)
  • IntValue (for values that are integers)
  • FloatValue (for values that are floating-point numbers)

The Value class is abstract, which means you can't make instances of it. The StringValue, IntValue, and FloatValue classes are "concrete", which means you can make instances of them.

docs.title: Input.java
docs.text:
The first thing we need to be able to do in our implementation is to read characters from an input source. There are three possible input sources: files, strings, and the terminal (i.e. keyboard input). In this file, we define an abstract class called Input, which contains an input buffer of characters. This class represents what an input source should be able to do. This class includes three methods:

  • getNextChar, which returns the next character in the input buffer. If there is no more input, it throws a NoMoreInputException exception.

  • putCharBack, which pushes a character to the beginning of the input buffer.

  • reload, which adds more characters to the end of the buffer. This method is abstract, so it has to be implemented in subclasses of Input.

The input data itself is stored in a data structure called a Deque (pronounced "deck", like a deck of cards). "Deque" stands for double ended queue. This is just an ordered collection of items (in this case, individual characters) that you can add to or remove from. We will be adding characters to the end of the deque when loading up the input, and removing them from the front as we process them. We will also sometimes add them back to the front (the putCharBack method) as needed. The deque acts as a buffer, so that many characters can be added all at once (e.g. a line of characters) but they can be removed and processed one character at a time.

You will learn more about implementing deques and related data structures in CS 2. Here, we will just use the ArrayDeque data structure provided by the Java libraries.

We are supplying you with an implementation for both the getNextChar and putCharBack methods, which are both very simple. However, getNextChar calls another method called reload in the event that the deque has no more characters. This method is not defined in the Input class, and so it must be defined in its subclasses. There are three subclasses of Input, one for each kind of input:

  • FileInput (for input from a file)
  • StringInput (for input from a string)
  • StdInput (for terminal input)

We are providing you with partial implementations of these classes. Here's what you need to implement for each class.

Note

Do not use a catch-all exception handler (i.e. catching Exception) when handling errors in any of the Input classes. Instead, handle the specific errors that you know can be thrown. Any such error should be re-thrown as a NoMoreInputException.

docs.title: The FileInput class
docs.text:
In this class, the constructor has been supplied to you. It creates a new BufferedReader object which reads from the file, and sets the closed field to false, which indicates that the file is ready for reading. If the file doesn't exist, closed is reset to true.

You need to complete the reload method. It reads in the next line of the file (including the newline character at the end), and adds the characters to the current buffer (the deque of characters described above). Use the addLast method of the ArrayDeque class to do this, so that the characters get added to the end of the buffer.

Note that the readLine method of the BufferedReader class strips the final newline from a string, so you'll have to add it back.

Note

Don't read in the entire rest of the file in the reload method! Just read in one line at a time.

If an error occurs while reading the line, close the BufferedReader and set the closed field to true before throwing the NoMoreInputException exception.

docs.title: The StringInput class
docs.text: In this class, the reload method has been supplied to you, since a string can't be reloaded (the number of characters is fixed). You just need to complete the constructor, which should only take a few lines.

docs.title: The StdInput class
docs.text: This class reads from the terminal (System.in) instead of from a file or string. Therefore, instead of a BufferedReader it uses a Scanner. You need to implement the reload method, which should be straightforward.

docs.title: Parser.java
docs.text: This file includes several methods that are used to parse the different Value subclasses. In this program, "parsing" means converting strings into Java values. All the methods in this class are static methods (they belong to the class, not the instances of the class) and take an Input object (an input source) as their only argument. One method (parseInt) is supplied for you. You need to implement the rest of the methods.

docs.title: parseDigits
docs.text:
This method tries to parse decimal digits (i.e. digits in the range 0 to 9) from the input and returns a String consisting of all the digits in the order they occurred in the input. The method stops collecting digits as soon as it encounters a non-digit character or runs out of input. In the former case, push the non-digit back to the input. If no digits are read (either because there is no more input or a non-digit character was encountered), return the empty string (not null).

Note

We made this method public for testing purposes, but normally it would be private. How to test private methods, or whether you should even test private methods at all, is a controversial topic in the Java community.

docs.title: parseNumber
docs.text:
This method tries to parse a number (integer or floating point). If it parses an integer, it creates an IntValue from it and returns it. If it parses a floating point number, it creates a FloatValue from it and returns it. If it can't parse either, it returns null. In some cases, a parse error can happen, and if that occurs, it throws a ParseErrorException. This method returns a Value, so it's allowed to return any subclass of Value, including IntValue or FloatValue objects. (It will never return a StringValue object, of course.)

The parsing rules for numbers are as follows.

  • Integers consist of a sequence of one or more decimal digits, optionally preceded by the _ (underscore) character, which serves as a negative sign.

    Note

    We don't use - for a negative sign because it's used as the minus operator, as you'll see below. This makes the parsing rules simpler.

  • Floating point numbers are required to have a decimal point (.) and at least one decimal digit before the decimal point. They are not required to have a digit after the decimal point. Exponential notation (e.g. 1.23e4 or 5.4e-5) is not supported. Floating point numbers can be preceded by the _ character to create a negative number (like you can do with integers).

  • More than one _ character before a number (int or float) is a parse error.

  • If an integer is followed by a . character, it becomes a float.

A good way to parse numbers is as follows:

  1. Parse an integer using the parseInt method. This method is supplied for you, and handles the sign issues. It returns a String, not an int; don't convert it to an int yet! If parseInt returns null, return null from parseNumber. (parseInt can also throw a ParseErrorException, which you should just let pass through.)

  2. Get the next character from the input.

    1. If there is none, the number is an integer, so create and return an IntValue.

    2. If it's a . (i.e. a decimal point), this must be a float, so use parseDigits to get the fractional part, collect all the float characters (integer part, decimal point, and fractional part), and create and return a FloatValue.

  3. Otherwise, push the character you just read back to the input, and create and return an IntValue.

docs.title: parseString
docs.text:
This method tries to parse a string. If it's successful, it converts the string to a StringValue and returns it. If not, it returns null.

String syntax

In this language, strings are written with enclosing square brackets, like this: [hello, world!] and not like this: "hello, world!". The reason for this is that strings are mostly used as functions: the characters in strings are generally calculator commands that can be replayed back. The square bracket syntax is more intuitive for this purpose.

The characters in a string consist of the characters inside the square brackets, but not the enclosing square brackets themselves (much like the characters in a Java string don't include the surrounding quotes). Strings in the calculator language don't support any character escapes (like \n for newline or \t for tab), so you don't have to worry about that. Strings can include embedded newlines, so this is a string spanning four lines:

[this
is
a
string]

This doesn't require any special parsing code, since you may get newline characters from the input source.

The only other syntax rule is that internal square brackets must be balanced. So this string:

[a string with [square brackets] inside]

represents the string "a string with [square brackets] inside". Most importantly, the string doesn't end when you read the first ] character; it ends when you read the ] character that balances the initial [ character. This is the only thing you need to keep track of when you are parsing strings.

The method reads characters from the input one at a time, trying to parse a string. First, it must read the initial [ character; if it's not there, return null. (Make sure to push the non-[ character back to the input so it doesn't disappear!) Then parse characters one at a time, looking for the closing ] character. If the input runs out before that character is found, throw a ParseErrorException (don't just return null!), because that represents an unterminated string, which is not allowed. Otherwise, collect up all the characters, create a StringValue and return it.

You will find the StringBuffer class useful here for collecting the characters.

docs.title: parseValue
docs.text: This static method is in the Value class. It skips all leading whitespace characters in the input. (The Character.isWhitespace method will be useful here.) Then it reads a single character. If there is none, return null. Otherwise, push the character back to the input. If it was a [ (start of string) character, try to parse a string value using parseStringValue. If that works, return the StringValue; otherwise, return null. If the initial character wasn't a [ character, try to parse a number using parseNumber. Return the result (null if it fails or a number value if it succeeds).

docs.title: Register.java
docs.text:
This file defines the Register class, which represents a single "register", which is what the calculator language uses as variables. You might expect that a register is just a slot where a single value can be stored, but in fact, each register is a separate stack of values. The main reason for this is that there are a limited number of registers (26, represented by the letters a through z). To enable more complex calculations to be performed, any register can be used as a stack, and then (for instance) each calculator function can use the same registers without having to overwrite values from other functions.

The register's stack is initialized in the constructor, which is provided. There are a few simple methods that you need to implement.

docs.title: empty
docs.text: This method returns true if the register's stack is empty, or false otherwise.

docs.title: storeTop
docs.text: This method replaces the value at the top of the register's stack with the argument value. If the stack is empty, it pushes the value onto the stack.

docs.title: storePush
docs.text: This method pushes a value onto the register's stack, whether the stack is empty or not.

docs.title: loadTop
docs.text: This method copies and returns the top value of the register's stack. (The stack's contents do not change.) If the stack is empty, it throws an EmptyStackException.

docs.title: loadPush
docs.text: This method pops and returns the top value of the register's stack. If the stack is empty, it throws an EmptyStackException.

docs.title: Ops.java
docs.text:
This file defines the Ops class, which contains static methods for computing with Values. Some of the methods are supplied for you, and most of the others can be written by using the supplied code as a template.

This file also is an example of the "algebraic datatype" pattern discussed in lecture 8. It's not object-oriented at all! If we wanted to write this in a more object-oriented style, we could have moved all these operations to the Value class, but that would have made that class a lot larger, and wouldn't provide any particular benefit. Since each Value object is actually one of the three concrete subclasses of Value (IntValue, FloatValue, or StringValue), each method has to inspect each Value using the instanceof operator to find out which concrete class the object belongs to. Once it has done that, it gets the contents of the object using the getContents method for that class, and carries out the computation.

Many of the methods are binary methods; they need to inspect the classes of both Value arguments. For numeric operations, we recommend you do nested instanceof tests (the outer one for the first Value, the inner one for the second), because often you can do an operation on arguments of different types. For instance, you can add integers to floating-point numbers and vice-versa, although you can't add either of them to strings. You can see an example of this in the supplied add method, which implements addition of values. We do overload addition to mean string concatenation when adding strings, but that is a special case (subtraction, multiplication etc. don't work with strings and numbers).

The comparison methods (equals, lessThan, greaterThan) should all be implemented in terms of the supplied compare method. They return integer values which represent booleans: 0 represents false and 1 represents true. The not method is included instead of lessThanOrEquals etc. because a <= b is the same as not(a > b). not only works on integer values treated as booleans; treat any nonzero value as true.

Any method that is applied to a Value that can't be used (like applying the not method to a StringValue) should throw an InvalidOperationException.

docs.title: Stretch goals [OPTIONAL]
docs.text:
It's not required, but it's quite easy to add more functionality to this class. For instance:

  • Extend the multiply method to handle Python-style multiplication of integers by strings (where the string is replicated an integer number of times).

  • Add a power method that raises one value to the power of another. This will only work for numbers, of course, and you may wish to have more restrictions (e.g. only allowing integer powers). Use the ^ character for the power operator.

  • Add and and or operators to allow combining tests.

If you do this, you may need to extend the calculator syntax in the SC class, which we turn to next.

docs.title: SC.java
docs.text:
This is where all the code finally comes together to make a working calculator program!

This file defines the SC class, which is the primary class of the program and the one that provides the user interface to the calculator (among other things). Many of the methods in this class are supplied for you, including the main method and the constructor. The two methods you need to complete are evaluateCommand and binaryOp, which we'll describe below.

docs.title: Fields
docs.text:
The SC class defines three fields:

  • inputs: an ArrayList of input sources.

  • stack: a Stack of Values, which is where the computations actually take place.

    Note

    Don't confuse this stack (which we will call the stack) with the register stacks described above (which we will always refer to as register stacks).

  • registers: a map between characters (a to z) and the registers that they represent. A "map" in this context means a data structure that lets you look up the register corresponding to a particular character.

docs.title: The main method
docs.text: The main method (supplied to you) processes the command-line arguments (if any) to determine which input sources exist for the current run of the program. It then creates an instance of the SC class and runs it (see below for more on the run method).

docs.title: The SC constructor
docs.text: The SC constructor (supplied to you) initializes all the fields of the calculator object. It receives an ArrayList of Input sources as its argument and stores that. It creates an empty stack. Then it creates all the registers and binds each one to a different character from a to z in a HashMap (which is a kind of Map).

docs.title: Other supplied methods
docs.text:
• run: This calls runInput on each input source.

  • runInput: This repeatedly runs evaluate on an input source until there is nothing left to evaluate.

  • evaluate: This tries to parse a Value from the input source. If it succeeds, the value is pushed onto the stack. If it fails, it assumes that the first characters of the input represent a command, so it calls evaluateCommand.

  • handleError: This just prints an error message to System.err.

docs.title: evaluateCommand
docs.text:
This is the primary method of the entire program. It's called when the next characters of the input source do not represent a value. Instead, the first character represents a command. This command is used to select an operation to perform (in a big switch statement). Some of the code for the commands has been supplied to you, but you'll have to implement most of the commands yourself. Usually, this will involve popping one or two values from the stack, computing a result value, and pushing that value back onto the stack.

For instance, if the input was 1 2 + n, then first the numbers 1 and 2 would be pushed onto the stack (in the evaluate method, not in this method). Then the + command would be evaluated by this method, and it would pop the two numbers off the stack, add them, and push the result back onto the stack. Finally, the n command would pop the result (3) off the stack and print it.

Note that you don't have to worry about spaces in the inputs, since the getNextChar method of the Input class will discard whitespace.2

docs.title: Commands and what they mean
docs.text:
Here are the commands in the calculator language:

  • c: Clear the stack.

  • d: Duplicate the top stack item. Print an error message (using handleError) if the stack is empty.

  • f: Print the contents of the stack non-destructively (i.e. don't change the stack). The values are printed one per line, with the top of the stack being printed first and the bottom last.

  • k: Pop the stack and discard it. k stands for "kill".

  • l: Load a register's value by copying (not popping) the top of a register stack onto the stack. The register to use is the character that follows the l, so the command la means "load register a". Print an error message if the register character is out of range (not in a to z) or if the register stack is empty.

    Note

    Use the methods of the Register class for this and for all register-related commands.

  • L: Like l, but pop the register stack instead of copying the top value.

  • n: Pop the stack and print the value, with a newline. Print an error message if the stack is empty.

  • N: Like n, but don't print a newline at the end.

  • p: Copy the top of the stack and print the value, with a newline. Print an error message if the stack is empty.

  • q: Quit the calculator program.

  • r: Swap ("rotate") the top two stack items. Print an error message if the stack doesn't have at least two items.

  • s: Pop the top of the stack and store it into the top value of a register. The register is identified by the character that follows the s, so sb means "store to register b". Print an error message if the stack is empty or if the register name is invalid.

  • S: Like s, but push the value onto the register stack instead of storing into the top value of the register.

  • x: Pop the top of the stack, which should be a string. Print an error message if the stack is empty or if the value popped from the stack isn't a string. "Execute" the string by pushing the characters back onto the input source. (Make sure that the first element of the string will be the first command executed!)

    Note

    Here you can see how strings containing commands are basically the same as functions in more conventional programming languages.

  • ?: This command does conditional execution (like if/else in most languages). It pops three values off the stack, of which one is an integer representing a boolean, and the other two are strings representing the "then" and "else" clauses of the conditional. They should be arranged as "int|then|else" with the "else" clause at the top of the stack. If the int is 0, execute the "else" clause; otherwise, execute the "then" clause.

    If there are fewer than 3 values on the stack, or if they have the wrong types, print an error message.

  • +: Pop two values from the stack, add them, and push the result back onto the stack. Use the Ops.add method to do the adding.

    This and the next few commands are very similar, so we want you to factor out the similarity by defining a method called binaryOp. This method takes in a function that converts two values into a single value, as well as the name of the command for error handling purposes. It pops two values from the stack, applies the function to get a result value, and pushes that back to the stack. It also handles errors by printing out error messages when necessary.

    The supplied code for the + command contains a feature of Java we haven't discussed in class: lambda expressions. These are a way to very concisely represent a function (not a method!) in Java. In our case, the function converts two Values to a single Value. The function for the + command is:

    (v1, v2) -> Ops.add(v1, v2)

    whose meaning should be obvious. The next few commands can be implemented in exactly the same way.

  • -: See above.

  • *: See above.

  • /: See above.

  • =: See above.

  • <: See above.

  • >: See above.

  • !: This pops a value from the stack, computes the boolean NOT of the value, and pushes the result back to the stack. We can't use BinaryOp for this because it's not a binary function, but the code is similar.

  • #: This skips the rest of the line, up to and including the first newline character. It's used for writing comments.

  • ,: This command executes the (string) contents of a register. The register character must follow the , character. This command is a shorter way of writing l<register>x, so ,a is the same as lax. This command is useful to treat a register's contents like a function; to call the function just do ,r where r is the register name.

That's it for the calculator language, unless you want to add some more commands.

docs.title: binaryOp
docs.text: This method isn't strictly necessary, but it does significantly reduce code duplication in the evaluateCommand method. It takes as its arguments an Operator (defined in Ops.java) as well as the command name. The Operator argument should be a lambda expression, as described above. It executes the binary operator by popping two values from the stack, computing the result, and pushing it back to the stack. If an error occurs, it prints out an error message using handleError.

docs.title: Calculator language summary
docs.text:
Here is a summary of the calculator language.

  • q — quits the calculator program
  • 42 — pushes the number 42 onto the stack
  • _10 — pushes the number -10 onto the stack
  • 1.2 — pushes the number 1.2 onto the stack
  • _42.3 — pushes the number -42.3 onto the stack
  • [foobar] — pushes the string "foobar" onto the stack (without the quotes)
  • # — starts a comment which goes to the end of the line
  • c — clears the stack
  • f — prints the stack, one element per line, top of stack first
  • p — prints the top of stack element (with a newline), but doesn't pop it
  • n — prints the top of stack element (with a newline) and pops it
  • N — prints the top of stack element (without a newline) and pops it
  • d — duplicates the top element of the stack
  • r — "rotates" (swaps) the top two elements of the stack
  • k — "kills" (pops and discards) the top element of the stack
  • la — "loads" (copies) the value at the top of register a's stack
  • La — "loads" (pops) the value at the top of register a's stack
  • sa — "saves" (copies) the element at the top of the stack to the top of register a's stack
  • Sa — "saves" (pushes) the element at the top of the stack to the top of register a's stack
  • x — executes a string popped off the stack as a series of commands
  • ? — conditional: pops an integer and two strings off the stack; if the integer is 0, executes the string that was on the top of the stack, otherwise, executes the other string
  • + — pops two values off the stack, adds them, pushes the result back onto the stack
  • - — pops two values off the stack, subtracts them (<second from top> - <top>), and pushes the result back onto the stack
  • * — pops two values off the stack, multiplies them, and pushes the result back onto the stack
  • / — pops two values off the stack, divides them (<second from top> / <top>), and pushes the result back onto the stack
  • = — pops two values off the stack; if they're equal, pushes 1 back onto stack, else pushes 0
  • < — pops two values off the stack; if (<second from top> < <top>), pushes 1 back onto stack, else pushes 0
  • > — pops two values off the stack; if (<second from top> > <top>), pushes 1 back onto stack, else pushes 0
  • ! — pops one value off the stack; computes (NOT <value>), pushes back onto stack (integers only; pushes 1 if input is 0, 0 otherwise)
  • ,a — same as lax but more concise

Those are all the commands.

docs.title: Code examples
docs.text:
Here's a transcript of an interactive session with the language. Note that the output comes on the line following the input. The output is indented to make it easier to identify. (It's not indented when running the actual program.)

1p   # print the number 1
    1
1 2+p
    3
[foo]p
    foo
[foo][bar]+p  # add (concatenate) strings
    foobar
f    # print the stack, one per line, topmost item first
    "foobar"
    "foo"
    3
    1
cf   # clear and print the stack (it's empty)
1 0/
    /: invalid operation: can't divide by zero
1.2 3.4/n   # n pops the result from the stack
    0.35294117647058826
1.2 3.4/p   # p leaves the result on the stack
    0.35294117647058826
f
    0.35294117647058826
cf
[d*]ss  # "squared" function; store in register s
10,sn   # print the square of 10
    100
[d*rd*+]st  # "sum of squares" function; store in register t
10 20,tn    # print sum of squares of 10 and 20
    500
10 20ltxn   # long-winded way to call functions: load register t and execute it
    500
[d0=[k1][d1-,f*]?]sf  # recursive factorial function
10,fn
    3628800
20,fn  # will overflow :(
    -2102132736
[d2<[][d1-r2-,fr,f+]?]sf # recursive fibonacci function
5,fn
    5
10,fn
    55
15,fn
    610
20,fn
    6765
25,fn
    75025
30,fn  # This takes a while!
    832040

This test script tests every command in the language, and also tests some more complicated functions. To compile and run it, do this:

It will run the tests and let you know about any failures. (You might need to scroll up to find the error messages.)

  1. It's a filename glob, which is a kind of wild-card for filenames. ↩

  2. "Whitespace" means one or more non-printing characters, and includes space characters, newline characters, and tab characters, as well as a few less common ones. ↩

docs.title: Assignment 7: Stack calculator
docs.text:
In this project, you will be implementing a terminal-based calculator program. This program is based on (and inspired by) a very old program called dc (which means "desk calculator"). The dc program was actually the first computer language ever implemented on a Unix system, predating even the C language.

Note

If you're curious, this page gives a good overview of the dc program. Most Linux and MacOS operating systems still have dc available, though it's rarely used.

Although the calculator program is conceptually fairly simple, it's actually a full-fledged computer language, able to do quite sophisticated computations with a very small amount of typing.

docs.title: Welcome to CS 1x!
docs.text:
This course is called Intermediate Computer Programming. It's a course on programming for students who have already have a considerable amount of experience in computer programming. Therefore (unlike CS 1) we will not be teaching you "how to program" from scratch. Instead, we will focus on the program design process, as well as covering a number of areas that typically trip up even experienced programmers (e.g. recursion, exception handling, etc.).

This book serves as the official course document repository. We will be posting most of the course-related content in these pages, including:

  • the course syllabus (which you should read as soon as possible!)
  • the course collaboration policies (which you should also read as soon as possible!)
  • assignments

and anything else we consider useful.

Your feedback on these notes will be very helpful to us in improving them, so please let us know if anything is hard to understand or if something that should be here isn't.

Course-related material we won't post here includes:

  • lecture slides
  • assignment code zip files
  • some administrative information

These will be posted on the course Canvas page in the Modules section.

We hope you enjoy the course!
